entry.title: App Analysis: Zomato plans Uber integration
entry.content:
Zomato is planning Uber integration in its mobile apps. The integration will be in the form of a button shown next to the restaurant address. The button will show ETA estimate from Uber and tapping it would launch the Uber app if installed. It will allow users to quickly book a ride to the restaurant they like. One big problem (atleast in India) will be data quality, since not all restaurant locations are accurately mapped.

Apparently, this feature has been part of the app for a while but hasn’t been switched on. Uber has been getting a lot of negetive publicity lately and Zomato may be waiting for the controversy to blow over.

Here are some screenshots for comparison:

Disclaimer: this post is based on source based information as well as app analysis. Final implementation may be different.

entry.title: command line graphing: gnuplot
entry.content:
Who needs charts on the command line? If you have ever been stuck at an ssh prompt staring a bunch of data gnuplot is a must have tool. I was looking at response times over an ssh prompt and realized how I missed MS Excel. All this data would make much more sense as a chart! Apparently there are others who would agree with me and that’s the reason gnuplot exists.

Enter gnuplot gnuplot is a command line tool that generates complex plots from data. It has a lot of options and can generate the plots as PNG, SVG etc. But most importantly it can plot your data as an ASCII chart :). Bonus points I use gnuplot to check my nodejs logs:

This is a static plot but you can even plot animated graphs like this:

entry.title: Cloud9: IDE in the cloud
entry.content:
Cloud9 is a cloud based IDE that works completely within the browser. It even provides a full linux terminal within the browser. It is ideal to try out some open source language/framework quickly without doing the full setup.

Currently it supports nodejs, PHP, python and ruby out of the box. There are plans to support .Net in the future. It allows one-click deployment to cloud platforms like Azure, CloudFoundry and Heroku. PFB screenshot of my attempt at a simple nodejs program :).

entry.title: @benguild: Leaked screenshots of native Google Maps (Alpha) for iOS 6.
entry.content: @benguild:Leaked_screenshots_of_native_Google_Maps(Alpha)_for_iOS_6. benguild: Oh boy! Here we go. * It’s vector-based. * It’s got two-finger rotation to any angle. * It’s super fast. * 4-inch height of the iPhone 5 is supported! Here are some blurry photos. Ever since iOS 6 came out, we lost Google_Maps. However, Google has been rumored to be hard at work on their own…

entry.title: @ Google Mobile Partner Day - they are really pushing mobile ads in India!
Download Youtube subscriptions on a schedule
entry.content:
My BSNL broadband plan gives me unlimited data between 2 AM and 8 AM. I thought this would be a great time to download all my YouTube subscriptions. I could watch the videos the next day without using my download quota! I found a couple of great scripts to get the job done. I had to make a few changes to get them working on windows:

Prerequisites: 1. Cygwin or another shell for windows. 2. Python

Just run the subscriptions script like so: ./download-youtube-subscriptions.sh mandarlimaye Put this command in a batch file and schedule it to run whenever you like.
